description.narrative: Coordinating and communicating results of development interventions
This project is aimed at coordinating and reporting on development results that have contributed to transformational changes
independent political entity

1) functionality and effectiveness of coordination mechanisms in placed 2) Harmonised approach in place to support SADA 3) Status of implementation of the several recommendations aimed at improving medical services in the Clinic 4) number of harmonised procurement actions in placed 5) UN communication strategy in place

comment.narrative: 1) Existing coordination mechanisms for UNDAF monitoring and reporting is weak 2) Demands from government to support transformation agenda. e.g support to SADA 3) Increasing demand from staff for to transform the clinic and the kind of medical services it provides 4) Though Country team is delivering as one, common procurement services are not harmonised 5) Only a draft UN communication strategy exist

1) UNDAF Management Structure and Coordination Mechanism revised and Strengthened 2) Review and Strengthen UN coordination and support for SADA and other Government transformation agenda 3) Implement key recommendations to improve medical services access and quality. Undertake 2015 annual review of the medical facilities and identify locum doctor and relief nurse for the UN clinic 4) Conduct a joint market research and survey for vendors prequalification. sign joint LTA, and MoUs 5) Finalise the UN communcations strategy

1) UNDAF change management process has been initiated and the 11 Outcome collapsed into 4 thematic groups lead by heads of agencies 2) UNDP provided technical, financial and logistics support to SADA (ICT equiptment) and also supported SADA to develop an online spatial map 3) The Clinic has been revamped and process in place to recruit a UN physician at P3 level 4) target 4 could not be achieved 5) Draft Communication plan is in place

title.narrative: Hydrochlorofluorocarbon Phase-out Management Plan for Gh

description.narrative: Hydrochlorofluorocarbon Phase-out Management Plan for Ghana
This is a holistic programme aimed at a sustainable and cost effective phase out of HCFCs through inter-related institutional and regulatory measures, training and investment activities ensured.
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

•A regulatory framework for the control of HCFCs and other HCFC based refrigerants established and operational by January 2013 •16 refrigeration and air-conditioning-based institutions selected country-wide trained and certified to embark on conversion of existing HCFC based air-conditioning to run on Hydrocarbon refrigerant R290 •16 Workshop Owners issued with subcontracts to embark on conversion of existing HCFC based air-conditioning

comment.narrative: • Domestic refrigeration sub-sector has increased the use of HCFC-based refrigerant blends, typically R406a as interim replacement for CFC-12 and R502 refrigerants resulting in the phase-in of increasing amounts of used refrigerators and freezers. The base year of HCFC consumption is set from 2009 representing 77.3 ODP tones.

1) Finalise legal Framework for the Management of the HCFCs 2) Information materials for sensitizing of Focus Groups (Information for Importers, Distributors and Refrigeration Associations) 3)Operationalise and strengthen Refrigerant Recovery Retrofit Programme - Payment of incentives to sustain the programme -To sensitize cold storage end-users to buy into the incentive package of conversion systems from R22 to alternatives -Facilities converted running on alternatives to R22 4)Training/Retraining of refrigeration technicians -Training on HC safety for factories inspectorate division, importers, sales personnel and fire service 5)Training and retraining of customs officers (Kpetoe, Takoradi and Accra) 6)Operation of a refigeration training centre of excellence and establishment of 2 existing Refrigeration Training centers (South and North) - Supply of Equipment to the training centres

1) A draft legal framework for the management of HCFCs is in place. Upon approval the framework, will look for low green warming potentials alternatives to HCFCs with particular reference to Natural refrigerants thus putting in place measures to ensure appropriate management pf its use in the country. 2) Over 1000 Aircondition units have been converted from Non environmentally friendly refrigerants to run environmentally friendly refrigerants such as R 290. 3) A centre of excellence has been established in Accra and is running efficiently addressing capacity building needs of refrigeration students and refrigeration students alike. Since it started operating in 2015, it has so far provided training to about between 200-300 personnels. Additionallly discussions has been held with the Takoradi Polythenic and the Kumasi Polythenic to establish the centres of excellence to serve the southern and Northern zones respectively. 4) Additionally in order to embark on the training for custom officials at the border posts, a procurement process has been initiated for the supply of the refrigeration equipments to facilitate the training. The overall objective of the training is to enhance the capacity of customs officials to control the influx of unprescribed and adulterated refrigerants into the country.

description.narrative: This Project supports national systems like the National Peace Council to consolidate peace in the country
This Project supports national systems like the National Peace Council to consolidate peace in the country
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

-Existence of 10 fully functional regional peace councils in accordance with its Act -Number of conflict assessment studies commissioned and completed -draft NPC 5 year strategic plan (2012-2016) in place -Conduct 9 trainings for NPC Board, staff and police in quantitative and qualitative analysis, dialogue, mediation and negotiation skills, conflict management, tolerance -improved technical and operational capacity of NPC Number of studies produced providing information on the role of civil society in conflict mitigation -Number of women and youth trained and involved in electoral violence prevention -draft baseline report on SALW situation in Ghana Prepared

comment.narrative: -New NPC in place and 7 out of 10 regions RPCs functional -Conflict prevention initiatives are not guided by scientific background studies -NPC has no 5 year strategic plan (2012-2016) -Limited knowledge and skills of new NPC Board and staff, and the police in quantitative and qualitative analysis, dialogue, mediation and negotiation skills, conflict management, tolerance, trust, confidence building -NPC ACT (818) in place but staff need capacity support -No comprehensive baseline document on the role of civil society stakeholders in conflict mitigation -Limited capacity and involvement of women and youth in conflict prevention -inadequate, out dated data on small arms proliferation -Limited involvement of CSOs, women and youth in conflict prevention and mediation processes

1) The NPC/RPCs intervenes in at least 2 new conflicts in addition to the previous 6 conflicts by end of 2016 2) Train 30 traditional/religious leaders to intervene in at least two conflicts by end of 2016. 3) Capacity of at least 50 peace actors built (50% women) to intervene in election related violence, in 2015 and 2016. 3) SALW baseline survey published. 4) Women/youth intervene in at least 2 new conflicts by the end of 2016.

The NPC through its Regional Peace Councils intervened in more than 2 emerging conflicts. For instance the Brong Ahafo Regional Peace Council intervened in the Tuobodom and Kwapong conflicts, leading to relative peace and paving way for dialogue between the factions. Similarly, the intervention of the Upper East Regional Peace Council led to the reconstitution of the Bawku Inter-Ethnic Peace Committee, which brought the parties together, to find a lasting resolution to the conflict, rather than an externally imposed solution. The NPC also intervened in some ongoing conflicts in Hohoe and Alavanyo-Akonya. Though the training has not commenced, a significant milestone in this regard is the development of the training manuals, a primary tool for the training. The NPC with the support of the UNDP and the EU organized dialogue sessions with Governance Institutions (Electoral Commission, the Security Agencies, and the National Commission for Civic Education among others), the Media and Civil Society Organizations (CSOs). The sessions reviewed the work of these institutions in the 2012 election, highlighting the best and not so good practices with a view to strategizing for election 2016. The respective institutions enhanced their knowledge on what they can do to ensure a credible and peaceful 2016 election. Though the SAWL has not been published, a major step is the validation and proofreading of the report, therefore making it ready for publication in the ensuing year. The capacity of over 30 women and youth were built in peacebuilding and mediation to enable them intervene in at least 2 emerging conflicts in 2016.

description.narrative: Capacities of governance institutions are built to promote enhanced service delivery and increased participation of citizens especially women, youth and other marginalised groups

title.narrative: Consolidating Representation adn Particpation 2014 Annual Progress Report
Annual Report for 2014 for R and P WP
SECOND QUARTER 2014 REPORT R and P WP
RP Steering Committee Minutes of Inaugural Meeting

description.narrative: Capacities of governance institutions are built to promote enhanced service delivery and increased participation of citizens especially women, youth and other marginalised groups
independent political entity
Elections - elections

-Local Government Service Secretariat produce monitoring report on decentralisation process -Local administrative staff trained in decentralisation process -debates organised on constitutional reforms -knowledge products on the code and NMC monitoring function produced and distributed -citizens more aware of about policy options in electoral agendas -increased capacity of EC staff, media and citizen to work together -increase in the rate of women and the vulnerable activity working toward reaching leadership and decision-making positions

comment.narrative: -Tracing mechanisms to assess decentralisation progress are weak -lack of awareness about decentralisation process among local administrative staff -limited public discussions and awareness of CRC recommendations -Breaches of the media code of conduct -Citizens not well informed about electoral agendas -need for more civic education content in the curriculum -level of public confidence in the administration of elections -low representation of women and vulnerable groups in decision making and leadership positions

1) : 40% (NB target will be appropriately adjusted when baseline is determined by GAP Poll ) of voter population have some knowledge in the proposed constitutional amendments recommended by the Constitution Review Report by 2016 (source GAP Poll 2016) 2) 60% of citizens trust the Electoral Commission to deliver on its mandate by the end of 2016 3) National policy on Popular Participation in Local Governance 100% developed and validated by end-2016 4) A Baseline of 76% of citizens who had not contacted any district assembly official in the past 12 months to discuss an important issue by the end of 2014 reduces to 70% by end-2016 5) total of 25,000 citizens participating in nationwide governance assessments by end of 2016 6) Six (6) initiatives established and/or supported to promote women’s participation in decision-making processes by 2016 7): Developed baseline on HIV related stigma and discrimination by 2016

The planned activities for the constitutional review could not be implemented as a result of a court injunction that was placed on the process since the last quarter of 2014. The case was determined and dismissed in the October 2015. The Committee has been meeting to plan public sensitization and a referendum. The Electoral Commission (EC) experienced a number of material changes in 2015 creating uncertainty and causing the trust of citizens in the Commission to decrease to 40% (Gap Poll 2015). The most significant change was the retirement of the EC Chairman who had been at the helm for 23 years. There were some public protests prior to the appointment which was finally made midyear. The new Chair who is external to the EC does not have any elections experience at the time of the appointment but is supported by two deputies who although have been with the EC longer are still relatively new to election management. Additionally the EC’s image has suffered somehow from many challenges in the aftermath of the 2008 and 2012 presidential elections. The Supreme Court in 2013 and subsequently a reform committee as well as the Inter-party Advisory Committee (IPAC) enumerated over 20 reforms for the institution. Finally the credibility of the Voters Register (VR) in its current state is in doubt. The leading opposition party in Ghana, the NPP has formerly requested for a new register for the 2016 elections on the basis that it is incurably flawed. This claim is resisted by the governing NDC. The EC has endorsed the recommendation to clean the current register by an eminent panel who investigated the positions and evidence presented by all political parties, civil society organizations and citizens in a public forum and its ensuing consultations. The EC recognizing the critical need to reposition the institution and further enhance its credibility, sought support from UNDP. Thus aA five year strategic plan for Electoral Commission to build their capacity to manage free

description.narrative: Promoting Inclusive Growth and Development.

title.narrative: INCLUSIVE GROWTH AND DEVELOPMENT ANNUAL REPORT 2014 annual report

description.narrative: The Annual Workplan on “Promoting Inclusive Growth and Development” supports Ghana’s vision of inclusive growth and development, as encapsulated in the Ghana Shared Growth and Development Agenda (GSGDA) 2010-2013.
independent political entity

-GLSS 6 conducted as per the long term survey schedule, and results released on a timely basis -GSS report on the analysis of he 2010 Census data -Commodities Exchange established -Number of communities using the sustainable low cost housing technology -ICT needs report of 20 selected communities completed and number of additional centres commissioned
-Number of sensitization and advocacy activities supported -National MDG report and MAF implementation and M&E reports and their contribution to policy planning and promotion of inclusive growth in Ghana available -Final GSGDA implementation progress report available -ICT policy reviewed and sensitization conducted -SADA and WR HDR report available -Functional and efficient systems strengthened to coordinate and oversee MDA -National LED policy and implementation Action Plan developed -Number of tools and training materials (communication strategy, citizens government and engagement, LED operational manuals) -Number of MMDA staff and stakeholders trained on the National LED tools -National LED inter sectoral platform established -The following products completed; most competitive product identified in each district; digitized online business register prepared; and number of trainings conducted on the digitized register for beneficiaries.

comment.narrative: -Long term survey calendar with specific surveys (2010-2025) available -Interim report on 2010 Population and Housing Census enumeration completed, and available in 2011 -Advocacy drive initiated in 2011 with TV discussions, community outreach in 3 regions, and in parliament -2008 MDG report and MAF (2010) available with country level data -GSGDA 2010-2013 available -Draft ICT Policy available -2011 Global and 12 District HDRs available -Architecture for coordinating and oversight of MDAs available at the Office of the President -Absence of coherent national policy framework on LED to support pro-poor inclusive growth(Report on mapping of LED initiatives in Ghana 2010) -Inadequate tools to support LED implementation -MMDA staff and other key stakeholders not yet trained on the National LED tools -No existing mechanisms to promote public-private dialogue in support of local economic development -Seven District LED strategies developed with UNDP support in 2011, but implementation of strategies not initiated -feasibility study on the viability of a Commodities Exchange in Ghana undertaken in 2009 -Sustainble low cost housing technology initiated in one district in 2010 -Two UNDP/MTN centres of learning commissioned in two communities in 2011

1) Updated demographic data from GDHS 2014 2) 10 GSS staff trained in multivariate analysis: 122 CPI data collection workers trained in the calibration of CPI digital weighing scales 3) Development planning model developed by December 2015 4) 2015 MDG report available by mid-year 2015 5) Costing framework for GSGDA II available by mid-2015 6)One-stop shop comprehensive development platform to facilitate spatial planning established by end 2015 7) Draft CMV by end 2016 8) Real time monitoring system for tracking SONA in place by 2015 9) Start running the GCX by mid-2015 10) At least 1 analytical study on spatial inequality; Model for mis-pricing in Ghana’s oil & gas sector; At least 1 study on mispricing and estimate of illicit financial flows; brochures

1)The GDHS 2014 report was launched in 2015, it provides updated outlook of the demographic and health of Ghanaians especially women and children. This will influence or guide policies and resource allocations related to maternal and child health 2) 10 staff of Ghana Statistical Service trained in multivariate analysis and were capacitated to prepare the Poverty Analysis report with the GLSS6 data earlier supported by UNDP and other partners in 2014 4) The Terminal report of the MDG was launched to help focus the National development discourse on the lagging goals. 5) The Costing Framework for the GSGDA II has been developed and this provides the financial gaps for development support in Ghana 6) With the support of UNDP a comprehensive spatial planning interactive maps have been developed covering the SADA ecological zones. It maps out the social, economic natural resource infrastructure for enhanced planning and development 7) UNDP supported initial consultative meetings across the country 8) A software (Dash Board) for monitoring SONA deliverables has been developed and being tested. It facilitated provision of inputs into the 3016 budget preparation. 9) The Ghana Commodity Exchange has been launched, it is expected the first bell to commence transaction will be in 2016 10) Target could not be met

description.narrative: The project seeks to deepen the culture and practice of transparency and accountability at the local governance level while strengthening the administration of justice and the capacity of citizens to access the legal system.

title.narrative: MINUTES OF UNDP STEERING COMMITTEE MEETING 532015

description.narrative: The project seeks to deepen the culture and practice of transparency and accountability at the local governance level while strengthening the administration of justice and the capacity of citizens to access the legal system.
independent political entity
Human rights affairs

-Number and level of consultations on policy formulationss and decision making -Number of citizens participating in local governance assessments (including vulnerable groups) district assembly debates validation workshops through APRM structures. -Increased public confidence in he administration of justice -increased numbers of women and vulnerable groups access the justice system

comment.narrative: -Inadequate engagements between citizens and governance/public institutions -noticeable low levels of citizens response to the Citizens Report Card (11,078 citizens), participation in the district assembly debates (1032) and validation workshop (11968) -Weaknesses in legal framework and institutional capacity hampering the delivery of justice -Paucity of legal professionals in specialised fields

1) Public service integrity programme operational 2) Review and adopt at least one anti-corruption legislation 3) Baseline reduced to 80% 4) 80 MDAs and MMDAs have published Client Charters by 2015 5) 460 cases reported and 400 resolved 6) At least one criminal justice institution operating a functional case management system 7) Baseline reduces to 60%

In 2015, National Anti-Corruption Action Plan (NACAP) implementation began with the finalization of a monitoring and evaluation framework to track progress. A public integrity programme was launched with designated Ethics officers from 35 Ministries, Departments and Agencies (MDAs) fully aware of their role in championing public sector ethics and integrity. Over 100 investigators of the Commission for Human Rights and Administrative Justice have improved capacity to investigate breaches of the code of conduct for public officers (President’s address at NACAP Conference; CHRAJ annual report) To implement UNCAC Ghana review report recommendation, two anti-corruption bills (Witness Protection bill, Conduct of Public Officers’ Bill) have been drafted while an existing legislation (whistle Blower Act) is being amended, the Conduct of Public Officers’ Bill and the whistle Blower Act Amendment bill are both at the consideration stage in Parliament, the Witness Protection bill is gone for cabinet approval. These were done through consultations with Parliamentarians, public servants and CSOs. (MoJAGD annual report; CHRAJ annual Report). As a result of the findings of the anti-Corruption baseline survey on the Customs, an integrity Manual and curriculum has been developed for staff training. Lessons learnt on the implementation of Client service charters in the past has been documented through a baseline survey conducted. The findings of this survey will guide the development of a prototype client service chapter for adoption and implementation by all public institutions for improved service delivery Speedy and efficient delivery of administrative justice cases achieved; 196 cases resolved of 236 cases received in 2015. This was possible due to the capacity building of CHRAJ staff on the effective and efficient handling of cases. In order to address comprehensively some of the key findings of the 2012 baseline such as lack of communication and coordination among the justi

title.narrative: Preparation of Ghana's Low Emission Cap. Building Proj.

description.narrative: Preparation of Ghana's Low Emission Capacity Building project proposal.
One UN Climate Change Action Framework" of the UN System Chief Executives Board for Coordination (CEB), through its capacity development group co-convened by UNDP and UNEP.
Implementation of Montreal Protocoll
GHA/SEV/72/INS/38 Support to EPA for the implementation of the Montreal Protocoll
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Number of targeted institutions that are compliant with Environmental Assessment Regulations LI-1652 of 1999

comment.narrative: The Executive Committee of the Multilateral Fund decision 33/12 decided that Governments (Government of Ghana) commit to ensure that:

1) Ensure Ghana's compliance with Article 7 and 9 of the Montreal Protocol by: - Reduction in ODS consumption and refrigerant end-users protected from the use of sub-standard refrigerants. This activity will also ensure compliance of Ghana's consumption of controlled ODS - To enable government make informed decisions and take appropriate policy actions - Reduction of ODS Consumption during servicing 2) Increased knowledge on the need to protect the Ozone Layer and related issues

1) In order to achieve target 1, a data collection exercise was conducted to assess national consumption of CFC for the year 2014. A report which detailed out a total of approximately 358,809.40 volumes of refrigerants ( R22,R 134a,R 406,R 407,R 5007 etc) collected was sent to the Montreal protocol secretariat in compliance with Article 7 and 9 for Ghana on the Montreal Protocol. Seemingly a survey was conducted to identify the different brands of refrigerant on the Ghanaian market whose outcome depicted the influx of mislabelled /adulterated and fake refrigerant on the Ghanaian market. Hence the need to put in place measures to address the capacity needs of the customs officials at the various borders/posts or entry points of the country. 2) A total of 881 students (500males and 331 females) participated in the awareness creation activity which aimed at increasing the knowledge of the young generation on the need to protect the Ozone layer.

description.narrative: Establishment of early warning systems to mitigate national disasters and empower communities to better manage disaster prepardness

title.narrative: CREW_Status Report of CREW Project as of September
REPORT ON THE CREW RESEARCH TECHNICAL WORKING GROUP WORKSHOP
COMMUNITY RESILIENCE THROUGH EARLY WARNING (CREW) PROJECT
Status Report of CREW Project as of September
MINUTES OF THE FOURTH PROJECT EXECUTIVE BOARD MEETING

description.narrative: This project aims to build capacities within the country to reduce disaster risk by putting in place an integrated early warning system that is both scientific and people-centered.
independent political entity
Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

1. Number of death arising from priority natural hazard events (flood and drought) 2. Total economic losses (in GHS amount) attributed to priority natural hazard events (flood and drought) 3. Number of people affected (evacuated, provided with aid) by priority natural hazard events (flood and drought) 4. Number and timeliness of EW issued/ communicated per disaster in a year or season 5. Number of hazards that had EW issued and acted upon to ensure safety 6. Systems are in place to gather data, analyze, develop and communicate early warning information on priority hazards 7. People-centered and multi-stakeholder involved EWS are in place for all major hazards, with outreach to communities. 8. National and district-level risk assessments information exist for priority hazards (flood and drought) in Ghana 9. A systematic, standardized process to collect, assess and share data, maps and trends on hazard vulnerabilities are established 10. Number of people and/or groups who know and understand hazard risks of priority hazards 11. Number of groups and/or communities implementing hazard risk reduction interventions 12. Number of maps produces or updated 13. A systematic, standardized process to collect, assess and share data, maps and trends on hazard vulnerabilities are established 14. An effective hazard monitoring and warning service with a sound scientific and technical basis is established 15. Communication and dissemination systems to ensure people and communities are warned in advance of implementing natural hazard events and facilitate national and regional coordination and information exchange are developed 16. The ability of communities to respond to natural disasters through enhanced education of natural hazard risks, EWS, community participation and disaster preparedness is strengthened 17. Institutional, legislative and policy frameworks and engagements that support the implementation and maintenance of effective early warning systems are developed 18. Na

comment.narrative: 1) Flood: 4 per annum (Drought: could not be determined ) 2) Flood: 177,281 (Drought: could not be determined 3) Flood: 2,420{Female 55%; Male 45%} {Children 51%; Adults 49% Drought: could not be determined 4) G-Met weather forecast, The Bagre Dam opening alert 5) Occasional announcements for potential heavy rainfall and the Opening of the Bagre Dam by NADMO 6) No existing system 7) No existing system 8) 5 MMDAs (1 CREW pilot site included) risk assessment by AAP 9) Uncoordinated and none standardized process 10) Pre training test results 11) Community volunteers upon NADMO instruction 12) 5 MMDAs (1 CREW pilot site included) produced by AAP 13) No coordinated and standardized processes – G-Met, HSD and WRC isolated systems and not functional 14 No existing system is in place 15) No coordinated system – NADMO, G-Met, HSD and WRC isolated systems and not functional 16) Occasional NADMO post disaster relief and recovery processes and post disaster situational reports 17/18) No existing system 19/20/21) Not explicit in the MTDP but in principle DRR is an objective 22)Systems exist with building codes but not enforced 23) Relief is the most popular post disaster intervention

1. Finalize the early warning gap analysis report 2. Printing and dissemination of the floods and drought risk maps to key stakeholders and the general public 3. Develop flood and drought risk profile of the 10 Pilot sites 4. Develop Early Warning Master Plan 5. Design and Implement Early Warning communication system 6. Propose Disaster risk mitigation measure in the 10 Pilot district 7. Initiate the implementation of DRR measures in 2 pilot sites 8. Train key national and district level staff in Early warning communication system and risk assessment 9. Install Seven Automated Weather Stations in Seven pilot sites of the project 10. Finalize the installation of WebEoc equipment at NADMO HQ and in the 10 Pilot sites

The following outputs have been achieved: 1. Comprehensive Early Warning Gap analysis for Floods and drought analysis at the national, district and community levels have been conducted. 2. Printing and dissemination of the floods and drought risk maps to key stakeholders and the general public have been done 3. Comprehensive floods and drought risk profiles of Ten Pilot districts have been developed 4. Early Warning Master Plan for drought and floods disaster at the national and districts levels have been developed 5. Early Warning Communication system have been developed and functional 6. Propose Disaster risk mitigation measure in the 10 Pilot district have established 7. Number of meetings with the districts focal persons to agree on the mode of implementation for Disaster Risk Reduction measures at the districts has been completed. Actually implementation will begin in 2016. 8. Conducted National, District and community levels training on early warning communication system and risk assessment for floods and drought disasters 9. Seven Automated Weather Stations have been installed and functioning at Seven out of the districts under the projects 10. Installations of WebEoc equipment at NADMO HQ and in the 10 Pilot sites have been completed.

title.narrative: Environmental Sustainability and Policy for Cocoa

description.narrative: Downstream and upstream intervention to contribute to sustainability of cocoa production in Ghana

title.narrative: FY2014 Annual Workplan Results and Resource Framework Revised
FY2013 Annual Workplan and Results and Resource Framework Jun13
Minutes joint steering comitttee meeting Final

description.narrative: strengthening capacities of stakeholders for more sustainable cocoa production
independent political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

-Number of key policy papers on harmonization of land and other sectorial policies related to the cocoa environment prepared and published -Number of farmers in Cocoa Life and pilot landscape communities enrolled in tree certification program -Number of community sensitization workshops organized for farmers in Cocoa Life and pilot landscape communities on forestry regulations and policies -Number of farmers –disaggregated by gender - and traditional authorities in Cocoa Life and pilot landscape communities sensitized on forestry regulations and policies -Percentage of farmers practicing safe and proper agro chemical application methods in Cocoa Life and pilot landscape communities -% of farmers adopting integrated crop management practices in Cocoa Life and pilot landscape communities -Number of spraying gangs formed to undertake commercial spraying on farms in Cocoa Life and pilot landscape communities -% of cocoa sector institutions including COCOBOD using GIS to improve land use planning -Number of government officials/farmers trained to use the environmental management system including GIS -Number of biological assessment completed & data used in the establishment of biological corridors
-Number of farmers trained in rehabilitation techniques -% of farmers adopting rehabilitation techniques
-Number of analyses carried out to strengthen basis for the development of pilots to inform national REDD strategies -Number of forums and dissemination workshops held to demonstrate tools, methodologies and approaches contributing to successful REDD activities -Events on REDD strategy development co-sponsored -Number of REDD proposal developed from the project support -Number of CREMAS developed with project assistance -Number of moribund CREMAs in Cocoa Life and other communities supported to regain functionality -% of forest within Cocoa Life Districts mapped -Percentage reduction in deforestation at cocoa frontiers in pilot landscapes and Cocoa Life communities

comment.narrative: 1) Phase I outcomes & lessons-learned 2) No national indicators have been established for cocoa 3) Limited knowledge of biodiversity in cocoa landscapes 4) 30% of cocoa farms are degraded and require rehabilitation 5) REDD readiness plan not fully developed 6) 90% of forests not engaged in sustainable management plans 7) 70% of farmers implement some form of environmental best practices 8) Cocoa farmers are not attached to any schemes for the payment of environmental services 9) Farmers generate limited income from additional sources

1. Climate Change Education program conducted in Junior High Schools and communities 2. CREMA developed and integrated within other activities using the “landscape approach” 3. Community spraying gangs supported to commercialize their operation in the Asunafo pilot landscape 4. Environmental sustainability and agricultural best practices mainstreamed into Cocoa Health Extension Division (CHED) under COCOBOD and the work of other Cocoa Life partners by developing training modules and training Community Extension Agents (CEAs) 5. Farmer sensitization and education campaign on forestry regulations and policies conducted to create awareness on farmers’ their rights under the law 6. Planting and registration of recommended economic trees by cocoa farmers promoted to increase tree and carbon stocks on farms. 7. Environmental sustainability content of the current extension training manual revised 8. Based on the findings and recommendations of both the tree and land tenure review studies conducted in 2014, land and tree tenure policy reforms discussed with key government institutions and the public

The project is continuing with its Climate Change Education program in Junior High Schools (JHS) and Communities in the Asunafo Pilot Landscape. In 2015, science teachers from 17 schools were trained on Climate Change and Environmental Sustainability, and 12 schools established model school cocoa farms. The development of a CREMA in the Asunafo Pilot landscape covering 36 communities has reached an advanced stage, with the formation of the CREMA Executive Committee and preparation of the CREMA constitution and the bye-law pending the District Assembly approval.
As part of the capacity building program, the project organized an orientation/technical training workshop on the forest laws and community rights for forest management for 12 Cocoa Health Extension Division (CHED) District Extension Coordinators (DEC) and 240 Community Extension Agents (CEAs). At the same time, farmer sensitization and education campaign was conducted in seven Cocoa Life districts to create awareness on farmers’ rights and responsibilities under the law. Training materials comprising a trainers’ manual, posters and a brochure developed last year were widely disseminated. The project also promoted planting and registration of recommended economic trees by cocoa farmers to increase tree and carbon stocks on farms. In 2015, a total of 523,100 tree seedlings were distributed to farmers in 428 communities across seven districts.
The project has collaborated with CHED and Cocoa Research Institute Ghana (CRIG) to revise the environmental content of the current Extension Training Manual for the use in the training of extension agents. The developed manual focuses on sustainable cocoa production practices and serves as a supplementary resource material to the existing cocoa extension manual approved by CHED.

description.narrative: Set up a multistakeholder platform where issues affecting the sector can be discussed.
independent political entity
policy, planning and administration

-Cocoa sector stakeholders adopt plans for improvements in the sector -Policy Framework for sustainable cocoa developed / reviewed -Number of cocoa sector policy reviews and reforms initiated and/or influenced cocoa platform -Number of cocoa sector coalitions and networks engaged in advocacy on cocoa issues -% change in government budget for improvements in the cocoa industry -Number of communiqués and position papers issued and published on cocoa sector issues -Cocoa Platform website created for information sharing across countries and commodities -Number of cocoa sector awareness, dialogue and advocacy programs on Radio and TV -Catalogue of global best practices on cocoa sector produced and shared across countries and commodities

comment.narrative: 1) National Cocoa Platform to facilitate stakeholder’s dialogue is non-existent 2) Global lessons on commodity platform are not conveyed to Ghana’s cocoa stakeholders
1. A study to assess mining's impacts on the cocoa sector finalized and disseminated 2. Technical committee meetings and plenary sessions organized with the new platform management unit under COCOBOD

In 2015, COCOBOD made a decision to mainstream the platform into their organizational structure. Following the decision, the platform coordinator was appointed from with the organization. The joint technical committee meeting was hosted in September, however the plenary session could not be organized due to time constraint.
A study to assess environmental and economic impacts of small-scale mining on the cocoa sector was finalized and presented at the joint technical committee meeting in September. The study outcomes will be further shared to the wider public and policymakers.

description.narrative: UNDP will provide strategic support to the Government of Ghana for the implementation of the Sustainable Energy for All Action Plan.

The project will support the establishment of a regulatory framework for the improved cookstoves market in Ghana and the development of an action oriented monitoring and evaluation of energy access system.
independent political entity
Energy - power generation
- Standards for improved cookstoves available - International impact oriented indicators available in the GEAR toolkit

comment.narrative: - Ghana developed the SE4ALL Action Plan, focused on the promotion of productive uses of energy and access to modern forms of fuels for cooking (e.g. LPG and improved cookstoves) - No technical standards for improved cookstoves available in Ghana - Impact oriented energy access indicators not identified and utilized in energy access measurements in Ghana

1) Technical standards for improved cookstoves gazetted 2) Testing and certification center at TCC fully operational by December 2015 3) Stakeholders educated on the cookstoves standards developed and the benfits of using improved cookstoves over traditional ones. 4) Zero used refrigerators entering Ghana market 5) 15,000 refrigerators exchanged through the rebate scheme

1, 2 and 3) The standards for improved cookstoves have been drafted by the mirror committee led by Ghana Standards Authority. This is done in parallel with the development of global ISO standards, which is receiving significant contributions from the Ghana Energy Commission. Comments have been received on the draft, however, it has been suggested to hold additional stakeholder consultations (in 2016) in order to receive as many inputs as possible, in particular from those stakeholders (like the manufacturers) who are going to be impacted the most by the enforcement of national standards. The Cookstove Testing and Expertise Laboratory was successfully established at the Technology Consulting Centre (TCC) of the Kwame Nkrumah University of Science and Technology (KNUST) and commissioned in March 2015, and is fully functional. The laboratory is meant not only to test cookstoves (especially to verify compliance with the standards, when published), but also to conduct research to further improve the technology. The management and business processes of the lab are being streamlined to ensure business sustainability. In order to promote awareness on improved cookstoves, radio jingles were developed in 6 different languages, and aired on 45 local and national radio stations. The maiden Renewable Energy Fair was successfully organized by the Energy Commission alongside the West African Clean Environment and Energy Conference. It constituted a platform to discuss the renewable energy sector (policies, challenges, success stories etc.) and to showcase public and private interventions in the sector.
4 and 5) UNDP supported some exit strategies for the Refrigerator Energy Efficiency Project, which ended in 2014. In particular, support was provided to do conduct quarterly compliance monitoring activities to cover all the regions. The main objectives were to check the labels fixed on the refrigerators in the various retail and outlet shops for compliance with the labelling guidel

description.narrative: The project will facilitate exchange of renewable energy expertise and technology between China and Ghana, building on China’s unique development experience.
The project will facilitate exchange of renewable energy expertise and technology between China and Ghana, building on China’s unique development experience.
Energy - power generation

1) Number of consultative meetings on RE policy and gaps in Ghana held. 2) Report on barriers for RET transfer produced 3) Report on criteria and specifications for selection of 4 RETs 4) number and type of training packages developed 5) number of reports and surveys developed and published; 6) Roadmap launched and disseminated; 7) Documents establishing PMUs and PSCs exist

comment.narrative: 1) Ghana adopted the Renewable Energy Act in 2011, but there is no master plan to implement it. 2) Barriers to effective transfer of Renewable Energy existed. 3) Currently, there is no demonstration site set up for Renewable Energy Technology Transfer (RETT) 4) There is no mechanism for up-scaling of RETs for Public-Private actors established, and capacity building required 5) The UNDP South-South Cooperation Framework 6) There is no existing mechanism for promoting Renewable Energy Technology Transfe 7) PMUs and PSCs haven’t been established.

1) Review of Chinese and Ghanaian Renewable Energy Policies conducted. 2) Report on barriers completed 3) Renewable Energy Master Plan developed 4) Stakeholder list developed; Project organization established; regular meetings held

1) A review of Ghanaian policies on renewable energy was conducted to identify gaps to address and opportunities to take in order to boost the sector and achieve the policy target of 10% of renewable energy (excluding large hydro) in the electricity generation mix by 2020. The review made concrete recommendations that will officially be presented to the Ministry of Power. These were also based on the experience from China, whose plans, regulations, strategies and incentives have made the country one of the largest producers of renewable energy. This review was conducted in a consultative manner (2 stakeholder workshops with 96 participants; 4 focus group discussions with specific stakeholder groups).
2) A study was conducted to identify barriers to renewable energy technology transfer RETT) to Ghana, and a road map developed to remove them. This was done by engaging several stakeholders at different levels. The study reviewed current technology transfer regulations; provided history of RETT in Ghana; identified specific political, economic/financial, market, institutional, awareness/information, technical, human skills, legal/regulatory, socio-cultural, and network barriers to RETT; detailed road map to address these challenges.
3) The main output for 2015 was the development of the Renewable Energy Master Plan. However, this was put on hold until 2016, as there was the need to complete other studies (like the policy review and barrier analysis mentioned above) and other government strategies (like the Strategic National Energy Plan) in order to fully understand the scope and content of the Master Plan. Preliminary activities have started, such as the development of a baseline for the Plan.
4) The Energy Commission initiated partnerships with Ghanaian research institutions to get technical support throughout project implementation, especially for the demonstration sites that will be created. These institutions will be paired with Chinese research institutions, in

An Inception report for the disaster preparedness and response action plans in 24 districts of the Northern Region has been submitted by the consultant.

description.narrative: Joint Party Support and Strengthening Project (J-PASS)
Other General Services - support to civil society

1) Levels of public trust in political parties (source: Afrobarometer/GaP Poll) 2) % of female party members willing to contest for leadership positions 3)Levels of public trust in the Electoral Commission (source: GaP Poll) 4) # of IPAC meetings held in election year 5) Number of polling station results submitted to J-PERM within 48 hrs of the close of poll

comment.narrative: 1) 50.5% of Ghanaians trusted political parties “somewhat” or “a lot” in 2012. 3) 57% of Ghanaians trust the Electoral Commission “somewhat” or “a lot” in 2014 to deliver on its mandate 4) 2 meetings held in 2012 5) 19,000 polling station results submitted in 2012

1) Gender Policies and strategies in women participation in political parties placed 2) International Best practices in internal political parties 3) Support main political parties to conduct a baseline and develop membership database 4) Relaunch the Project to gain traction and serve as resource mobilization tool 5) Participate in International best practice meeting and recommend solutions for local adoption

Consensus on issues of common concern among five major political parties has been built through an Inter-Party Platform established with support from UNDP as part of its Joint Party Support and Strengthening (J-PASS) project. Knowledge of 10 representatives (50% female) were improved to understand their commitment in enhancing women’s participation in political parties through their participation in an African High Level Dialogue on Democracy, Governance and Human Rights held in Kigali, Rwanda. Three studies on documenting best practices for the development of gender policies, membership data base and inter party communication policies for political parties have been commissioned with the draft reports ready for validation.

title.narrative: Green Climate Fund Readiness Programme in Ghana

description.narrative: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational.

title.narrative: Ghana Green Climate Fund Readiness Project
Ghana_GCF readiness_2015 work plan_REVISED June24 FINAL
Ghana GCF Prodoc signed and dated paged
Green Climate Fund Readiness Programme in Ghana
Green Climate Fund Readiness Programme in Ghana
Green Climate Fund Readiness Programme in Ghana

description.narrative: To support the Government of Ghana in strengthening their national capacities to effectively and efficiently plan for, access, manage, deploy and monitor climate financing in particular through the GCF once it is fully operational

- Number of national entities identified and assessed for National Implementing Entities (NIE) potential - Number of workshops held to strengthen climate change coordination - Reconstitution of the NCCC - Number of tools developed for economic and budget analysis of climate finance - Number of online knowledge management platforms to support project pipelines - Number of workshops to train stakeholders on prioritising procedures - Number of tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - Number of MRV templates developed

comment.narrative: - Ghanaian public and private entities not assessed for existing fiduciary governance capacity - No workshops held to strengthen coordination - National Climate Change Committee is not currently active - No tools developed for climate finance related economic and budget analysis - No online knowledge management platform to support project pipelines - No trainings for stakeholders on prioritising interventions - No tools developed to assess and design climate interventions - No MRV templates or guidance

1. Mapping and assessment of Ghanaian national public or private entities that are eligible to access funds from the GCF complete 2. Ghana’s climate change coordination across national and sub-national levels strengthened 3. Strengthening of climate change regulations, policies, plans and budgeting supported 4. Stakeholder access to information and knowledge products on climate change increased 5. Guidelines and procedures developed for prioritizing climate change needs and interventions 6. Market based and value chain business model tools developed to assess, design and measure climate change interventions, including Cost-Benefit Analysis (CBA) and project checklists and safeguards 7. Monitoring and evaluation (MRV) templates and guidance developed

The GCF readiness programme started implementation from June 2015 with the inception workshop, as the fund was only received to the country office in May. Following the inception, a half-day workshop was organized in August with the support from the GCF secretariat to increase stakeholder’s knowledge on the National Implementing Entities (NIEs) accreditation requirement and process. In November, National Designated Authority (NDA) for GCF, Real Sector Division of Ministry of Finance, advertised a call for application to identify potential NIEs candidates in Ghana. Capacity assessment of the identified entities will be conducted as a next step.
In order to strengthen climate change coordination, the project supported Ministry of Environment, Science, Technology, and Innovation (MESTI) to organize the National Climate Change Steering Committee. The committee reviewed Ghana’s progress in the preparation of Intended Nationally Determined Contributions to UNFCCC, and discussed the formation of working groups under the committee including climate finance working group.
The consultants were engaged to 1) develop the operational manual for NDA and 2) develop the climate change project prioritization tool. The prioritization tool will be used by national stakeholders to identify and prioritize the areas for GCF proposal development. Further, building up from the outcome of the Climate Public Expenditure and Institutional Review conducted by Ministry of Finance earlier this year, the project will support the development of the climate change budget and finance tracking tool.

description.narrative: Advocacy and capacity building for disaster risk reduction and preparedness in Ghana

title.narrative: GFDRR Project Proposal 8th draft to WB 4feb14
GFDRR Draft Project Document 8th draft to WB 4feb14

description.narrative: Advocacy and capacity building for disaster risk reduction and preparedness in Ghana

1) Report covering the celebration of the International Day for DRR 2) Minutes and approved programme for the annual review meeting of the national platform 3) Draft and final awareness creation materials submitted 4) Core Training Agenda developed 5) Report on regional and district simulation exercises organised.

comment.narrative: 1) The is annual event, and has been celebrated in previous year including 2014 2) National platform already exist 3) There are existing materials but need to be updated 4) There is existing literature and different training programmes with various academic and learning institutions 5) Similar prepared and awareness stimulation exercise are in place

1) Organize high level, public events, in particular within the context of the International Day for DRR, to raise awareness on specific topics and issues related to DRR in Ghana. 2) Support awareness and advocacy activities organized by the National Platform for DRR 3) Develop awareness creation material for disaster risk reduction and prevention. 4) Develop a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels. 5) Organize 1 regional and 1 district simulation exercises to strengthen disaster preparedness.

1) Two main events were organized to sensitize on Disaster Risk Reduction (DRR). The International Day for Disaster Reduction was celebrated in a disaster prone community called Anyamam, with focus on the importance of indigenous and traditional knowledge. In addition, radio discussions were held and a social media campaign was carried out around this theme. The second event is the annual meeting of the National Platform on DRR, which brought together the main stakeholders involved in disaster management. It was an opportunity to take stock of 2015 activities on DRR both at the regional and national levels, and to strategize on 2016 advocacy activities in line with the new Sendai Framework for Action.
4) A stock-tacking exercise was conducted to map out existing DRR programmes or trainings in tertiary institutions and identify gaps. On the basis of this, a core training agenda addressing disaster risk reduction and management for government cadres from various administrative levels was developed and validated by stakeholders from tertiary education institutions. The actual programs will be developed and carried out in 2016.
5) A regional simulation exercise was organized in the Upper West Region, using floods as disaster scenario. The aim was to assess the preparedness and response capability of major stakeholders in disaster risk management, test effectiveness of the existing contingency plans, and evaluate the co-ordination level among these stakeholders. About 230 participants from national, regional, and district level institutions participated. A debriefing session with 70 participants was held to discuss main issues and recommendations.

description.narrative: 1) No stock out of reagents and supplies for testing EVD; # of temperature screening equipment installed 2) Number of personnel trained; Number of situation reports expected generated; Number of protective and preventive items provided; Number of immigration officers trained; Number of entry/exit sites that conduct EBV surveillance; Childhood disease management protocol available; Number of community-based surveillance volunteers trained

comment.narrative:
The Ebola Virus Disease (EVD) outbreak was first reported to WHO in March 2014. As at 29 October 2014, about 14,000 cases and nearly 5,000 deaths have been recorded mainly from the three most affected countries, Guinea, Liberia and Sierra Leone.
Ghana is considered as being at high risk of importation of EVD in view of a combination of varied number of factors which have the potential to trigger an outbreak which will have a devastating impact on health, economic, social, security and overall development of the country. Some of these factors include

Though no Ebola case has been registered in Ghana, the UN system under and the UN Coordination framework continuous to coordinate and liaise with development partners and government to keep the country in readiness and out of risk.
